title: What is the difference between property management and asset management? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s like the difference between the restaurant owner (asset) and the head chef (property). The owner is concerned about overall financial position, growth, profit, and administrative overhead such as taxes, insurance and bank loans. The chef is in the chaos of day-to-day operations. Serving clients, dealing with complaints, getting customers in the door, maintaining the equipment/facility. I’ve been both. Asset Management is the far easier workload. But, then again, some people just love whipping together a great menu and checking in on diners to see how well the meal is being received.

A Property Manager typically deals with the day to day operation of a property, such as  - Rent collection- Payment of Property's ordinary operating costs- attending to tenants' maintenance requests- Service of eviction notices in the event of non-payment- Accounting services However, an Asset Manger deals with more fundamental and strategic issues related to a property, such as: - Hiring and firing of a property manger- Renovation and upgrade of the property- Refinance of the property- marketing and disposition of a property - Aaron Yashouafar

Property managers typically deal closely with the tenants or renters of a property. They handle any issues with rent, eviction notices or anything of that nature. They are often called landlords as well. On the other hand, the asset manager deals with pretty much everything else that doesn't involve the tenants. http://www.vintage-corp.com/

Property management Gordon Rutty in Australia concentrates on the day to day operations of a property. On the other hand Assets management is centered on financial matters,maximizing the return on investment and value of property.
